text:
August 1, 2014
by Carole Zangari - 
				7 Comments
 We had a lot of fun with the post “You Might Be an AAC Therapist If,” especially in reading all the contributions from our prAACtical friends. Along those same lines, here are some questions that we’ve asked ourselves a few (dozen) times. How about you? What AAC-related questions do you ask yourself? Filed under: PrAACtical Thinking Tagged With: AAC Therapist, questions, therapist This post was written by Carole Zangari Asking Good Questions During Interactive Book Reading with AAC Learners You Might be an AAC Therapist If… Beyond Requesting: Thoughts on Teaching Interrogatives How to Use Magnets to Promote Language Development I love these – and have done most of them. My question is “Is it rude to ask dinner guests to stay after dinner and help me cut up a PODD?” Love that one, Jane! Ha, Jane! Mine is more like “Is it rude to ask people over for dinner so they can cut PODD books? If so, do I really have to feed them since they’ll have to put down the paper and scissors to eat?”
My other main question is “How many times do I have to ask people not to use The Good Scissors to cut Velcro????” Oh – Mary Louise! That’s brilliant. Of course I don’t have to feed them – what was I thinking! Is it ok to velcro shut a teacher’s mouth after they tell you they had to take the student’s SGD away because “he was talking too much”!?!? Not a question but more of a restatement:  So what I hear you saying is that you would like ME to do all the programming… by tomorrow! Great post Carole! Thanks for sharing. PrAACtical AAC supports a community of professionals and families who are determined to improve the communication and literacy abilities of people with significant communication difficulties. It was founded in 2011 by two SLP professors, Carole Zangari and the late Robin Parker, around a shared passion for AAC. 
 Follow Us Follow Us  PrAACtical AAC's Mission: To improve the level of AAC services available to individuals with significant communication challenges by supporting speech-language pathologists and other interested stakeholders
